This page archives the details and updates of the Kingdom Death: Monster 1.0 Kickstarter campaign.

Campaign.
The Kickstarter campaign launched on November 22, 2012. The campaign had a fundraising goal of $35,000. The campaign met its fundraising goal within 1.5 hours of launch. The campaign ended on January 7, 2013, raising $2,049,721 with 5,410 backers.

Updates.

This page archives the details and updates of the Kingdom Death: Monster 1.5 Kickstarter campaign.
Campaign.

The Kickstarter campaign launched on November 24, 2016. The campaign had a fundraising goal of $100,000. The campaign met its fundraising goal and surpassed the 1.0 Kickstarter ($2.05 million) 2 hours after launch. At 19 minutes into the campaign, it set a record for fastest project to reach $1mil raised (previously held by Pebble Time, at 49 minutes).CNBC.com, Board game raises over $10 million, becomes one of the most successful Kickstarter campaigns ever The campaign ended on January 7, 2017, raising $12,393,139 with 19,264 backers. This made Kingdom Death: Monster 1.5 the 4th most funded project on Kickstarter, and the 1st most funded tabletop game product.Kickstarter.com, Most Funded Projects

Updates.

References.

is a custom campaign found in the Flower Knight Expansion. It can modify any existing campaign, such as the standard campaign. It tells the story of a settlement located close to The Forest Gate, and worships the Flower Knight as a deity.
Story Events.
The campaign does not add new story events to the Timeline, except to periodically add population losses to help trigger the Sleeping Virus Flower event.
Development.
During the develop step of the settlement phase, the survivors may choose to trigger the Sense Memory story event, perform a Forest Run, and craft the Flower God Helm and Replica Flower Sword gear.
Other Changes.
Due to their proximity to The Forest Gate, newborn survivors have +1 permanent luck, +1 permanent green affinity, and -2 permanent red affinities. Additionally, all survivors are immune to the Flower Addiction disorder, and due to their reverence, are unable to hunt the Flower Knight. The Sleeping Virus Flower was already present when the survivors founded their settlement.
Sources.
Official Rules can be found on Page 1, Column 3 of the Flower Knight Expansion booklet.

is a custom campaign found at the end of the Core Game rule book. It can modify any existing campaign, such as the standard campaign. It tells the story of a settlement who worship skulls above all else. They only wear weapons and armor with the bone keyword, and ignore the frail rule.
Story Events.
The campaign does not add new story events to the Timeline.
Development.
During the develop step of the settlement phase, the survivors may choose to perform a Skull Ritual.
Other Changes.
Survivors with the word bone or skull in their name gain an +1 permanent accuracy, evasion, strength, luck, or speed.
If a weapon or armor is made with the Black Skull resource, a survivor may place it into their Gear Grid despite being iron.
Sources.
Official Rules can be found in the Game Variants section of the Core Game Rule Book.

is a campaign in the Dragon King Expansion. It is an alternative to the standard campaign that features its own timeline, settlement location, story events, innovations, nemesis monster, and abilities. It tells the story of a settlement around the throne of a fickle, aging tyrant who tries to mold the survivors into a mighty people to carry on his legacy.
Story Events.
The timeline begins with Foundlings (instead of Returning Survivors), ends with Death of the Dragon King, and uses other story events in place of some of the events on the standard timeline. Bold and Insight are replaced by Awake. Intimacy is replaced by a different event with the same name. The following events are totally excluded from this campaign and cannot be triggered or added to the timeline: Hands of Heat, Regal Visit, Armored Strangers, Watched, and Showdown: Watcher. Additionally, there is no milestone to trigger Hooded Knight for .
Innovations.
In the campaign, Language is replaced by Dragon Speech, Family is replaced by Bloodline, Clan of Death is replaced by Empire, and Lantern Oven is replaced by Radiating Orb (which cannot be innovated normally, only gained from Midnight's Children). Arena is also included as a consequence of Nightmare Training.
Constellations.
Survivors in this campaign collect Dragon Traits to complete constellations that grant unique abilities. These are recorded on a non-standard survivor record sheet.

is a campaign in the Sunstalker Expansion. It is an alternative to the standard campaign that features its own timeline, settlement locations, story events, innovations, and survival actions. It tells the story of a settlement around a pool beneath the sun in the sky.
Story Events.
The timeline begins with The Pool and the Sun (instead of Returning Survivors), ends with The Great Devourer, and uses other story events in place of some of the events on the standard timeline. Intimacy is replaced by a different event with the same name. There are no milestones to trigger Principle: New Life or Hooded Knight. Instead, the settlement always uses Survival of the Fittest and a new milestone triggers Edged Tonometry.
Innovations.
In the campaign, Language, Inner Lantern, and its consequences are replaced by Sun Language, Hands of the Sun and its consequences. Additionally, Umbilical Bank is gained via Birth of Color. 
Other Changes.
Due to their unique innovations, survivors in this campaign learn Embolden instead of Encourage and Overcharge instead of Surge. They may not wear heavy gear and they can trigger Game Over by failing any of the five nemesis showdowns that appear on the last five years of their timeline.

Seven Ageless Sword Masters face the darkness alone. They accept no outsiders, and hold no love in their hearts, never rolling on the intimacy table. Their population never grows: when the last swords master falls, so does the settlement.

One survivor among the founding survivors, awakens with a strange sword in their hands in addition to the dried ink over their eyes. They find it comfortable, and have 3 weapon proficiency ranks with it. They cannot gain age tokens, can still hunt when retired, will never skip a hunt, and will always depart. Reaching max proficiency does not cause the knight to leave the settlement. If the knight dies, the settlement descends into Hopelessness.
